Governor Brown will talk to the faculty about…; Next Thursday, the high school faculty will… Simms looked over the students’ leads and set them aside. 

He then told them they were all wrong. The real lead was, “There will be no school Thursday.” 

Ephron remembered, “In that moment, I realized journalism isn’t just about spitting out facts. It’s about finding the point. You need to know the who, what, when, and where, but you also have to understand what it means and why it matters.” She added, “He taught me something that applies to life just as much as it does to journalism.” 

In every set of facts, something crucial is hidden. A good journalist digs into those details and figures out how they connect. It’s about making those connections clear. It’s about piecing together the whole from its parts and understanding how they matter to anyone. The best journalists don’t just share info; they find what truly matters to people. 

Have you ever felt lost and unsure about what to focus on? Overwhelmed by info coming at you? Dazed by different requests and unsure which ones are important? Ever missed the point in your work or at home and only realized it too late? If you’ve answered yes, this next Essentialist skill will be super helpful. 🚀

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Good journalism involves uncovering the essential meaning behind facts, helping people focus on what truly matters amidst overwhelming information.
